recommendations: Prioritize CT Pulmonary Angiography (CT PA) given the emergency admission for chest pain, but proceed with caution due to hypotension and moderate CKD.
Administer IV hydration (e.g., isotonic saline at 1 mL/kg/hr, adjusted for hypotension) 12 hours prior to and 6-12 hours post-contrast, with careful monitoring of fluid balance and blood pressure.
Obtain a repeat serum creatinine with an exact timestamp prior to contrast administration to confirm current renal function.

Consider an alternative imaging modality such as a Ventilation/Perfusion (V/Q) scan if the patient's hemodynamic status or renal function deteriorates, or if the risk of contrast-induced nephropathy is deemed unacceptably high.
rationale: Patient presents with symptoms concerning for pulmonary embolism, for which CT PA is the diagnostic standard.
Hypotension (MAP 59 mmHg) and Stage 3a CKD (eGFR 59 mL/min/1.73m²) increase the risk of contrast-induced nephropathy and may be exacerbated by contrast agents.
The elevated BUN/Cr ratio (20) and creatinine (1.7 mg/dL) suggest potential prerenal azotemia, necessitating careful management of hydration and blood pressure.
A V/Q scan offers an alternative for PE diagnosis with no iodinated contrast exposure, reducing renal risk.

protocol_selection.name: CT Pulmonary Angiography (Chest CTA for PE)
protocol_selection.description: CT angiography timed for pulmonary arterial phase (6–13 sec post-contrast) to evaluate pulmonary arteries for embolism.
protocol_selection.contrast_dose: Weight-based; ~100–150 mL iodinated contrast (300 mg I/mL); follow ACR Manual.
protocol_selection.renal_safety_notes: Ensure contrast-to-eGFR ratio <1.1 g/(mL/min); if eGFR <30, consider non-contrast alternatives or weigh risks carefully.
